descriptions:
Here is a 289-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: Decentralized Markets with Informational Asymmetries

This project seeks to advance the theory of decentralized trade in the presence of informational asymmetries and limited commitment. In most trading situations, parties have unequal information, leading to market inefficiency. For instance, professional investors possess more information than individual investors in financial markets, and consumers have private information about their willingness to pay. The standard theory of mechanism design assumes strong commitment, which is often unrealistic, and existing literature focuses primarily on single-instance trading. This project aims to fill this gap by systematically analyzing decentralized markets with repeated trading and informational asymmetries using game-theoretic tools.

The project's objectives are fourfold: (1) to understand the properties of commonly used trading mechanisms, (2) to explore remedies for enhanced efficiency, (3) to contribute to the design of market institutions, and (4) to inform market regulation. The research will focus on repeated transactions in non-durable goods and services, as well as durable but divisible goods. By providing insights into the functioning of decentralized markets with informational asymmetries, this project will improve our understanding of market efficiency and inform regulatory policies to promote more efficient market outcomes. Ultimately, the project's findings will have significant implications for the design of market institutions and regulatory frameworks that facilitate efficient trade in a wide range of economic contexts.
